title: 107_s2445
content: The Act may be cited as the "Book Stamp Act". The "Book Stamp Act" acknowledges the importance of literacy and the need for increased investments in child literacy. It highlights the significance of increasing access to books in homes through existing distribution channels. The Act defines terms like "early learning program" as activities for children under 6 to develop skills for school readiness, "Secretary" as the head of Health and Human Services, "State" as various regions, and "State agency" as a regional governing body. The term "State agency" refers to a regional governing body designated under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. "Grants are provided to State agencies." The Secretary will establish a program to promote child literacy and improve access to books in various programs. Grants will be provided to State agencies for this purpose. The State must submit an application to the Secretary to receive funds under this section. Accountability measures from the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 apply to State agencies receiving grants under this Act. In this section, "available funds" for a fiscal year include funds from section 417(c)(1) of title 39, United States Code, and amounts appropriated under section 9. SEC. 5. A State agency receiving a grant must contract with local child care resource and referral agencies to carry out activities. Up to 3% of funds can be used for a public awareness campaign. SEC. 6 outlines the use of funds. The child care resource and referral agency receiving a contract under section 5 must use funds to provide payments for eligible providers to make books available for child literacy and access to books in various programs. Eligible providers include center-based, group home, and family child care providers. Entities eligible to receive funding under section 5 must meet specific criteria, such as being a Head Start agency, providing early learning programs, hospital-based or clinic-based literacy programs, library-based literacy programs for children under age 6, or nutrition programs at clinics. Entities eligible for funding under section 5 must meet specific criteria, such as being a Head Start agency, providing early learning programs, hospital-based or clinic-based literacy programs, library-based literacy programs for children under age 6, or nutrition programs at clinics. A child care resource and referral agency that receives a contract under section 5 to provide payments to eligible providers must consult with local individuals and organizations concerned with early literacy. Eligible entities must serve children under age 6 in areas where they face high risks of literacy difficulties, as defined by the Secretary. Entities eligible for funding under section 5 must meet specific criteria, such as being a Head Start agency, providing early learning programs, hospital-based or clinic-based literacy programs, library-based literacy programs for children under age 6, or nutrition programs at clinics. A child care resource and referral agency that receives a contract under section 5 to provide payments to eligible providers must consult with local individuals and organizations concerned with early literacy. Eligible entities must serve children under age 6 in areas where they face high risks of literacy difficulties, as defined by the Secretary. Pediatricians, directors of the special supplemental nutrition program for women, infants, and children, literacy coalitions, and organizations carrying out specific programs are required to coordinate local book distribution needs, gather demographic information, and distribute books to eligible providers every 6 months. Entities eligible for funding under this Act must provide books to children every 6 months, use a small portion of funds for training, and offer parent workshops on reading readiness. Federal funds can only be used to purchase books at standard industry terms for nonprofit programs. Entities eligible for funding under this Act must provide books to children every 6 months, use a small portion of funds for training, and offer parent workshops on reading readiness. An entity offering books for purchase under this Act must meet specific terms, including a 43 percent discount off the catalogue price of the books with no additional charge for shipping and handling. The child care resource and referral agency administering the funds cannot use more than 6 percent for administrative costs. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 2 years of the Act's enactment. Additionally, special postage stamps for child literacy are authorized. Chapter 4 of title 39, United States Code is amended to establish special postage stamps for child literacy. The Postal Service will offer a discounted rate for first-class mail with stamps promoting childhood literacy. The postage rate will be the regular first-class rate plus a differential of up to 25 percent, set by the Governors following specific procedures. The special rate of postage for child literacy is voluntary for postal patrons. The Postal Service will pay 100 percent of the amounts available for child literacy to the Department of Health and Human Services. Payments will be made at least twice a year under mutual agreement with the Department to carry out the objectives of this section. Child literacy under this section refers to the funds received by the Postal Service, minus costs incurred for printing and distributing stamps. Congress emphasizes that this section should not reduce funds received by the Department of Health and Human Services or any other government agency. The special postage stamps made available under this section will be accessible to the public within 12 months of enactment. The Postmaster General must report on the operation of this section in each report, including the total amounts received by the Postal Service. The section will cease to be effective after 2 years from the date the special postage stamps are first available to the public. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS: $50,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year from 2003 to 2007.
